#GullyBoyWill you change #dream to accept reality or chase down your dream to change reality? The movie has got the answer to it..The slumdog raps up his dream to become rapstar sensation who declines to surrender to circumstances encompassing his life. #GullyBoy is in inspirational movie and also a path breaker milestone movie of youths.The movie journey begins in #Mumbai #dharavi slum with life of a ordinary non-directional guy to charged up rapper and #HipHop #YouTube star. The #GullyBoy is multifaceted, he roles up as car thief to driver to sales guy before he realises where his future lies. The center character has all neighborhood surroundings which can make or break the person - grown up in slum, abusive father, unhappy mother, 4x4 room, intimidating possessive girlfriend, petty criminal friend but he got his passion, childhood lover, a role model and mentor, project album angel then there is dream to chase. The story builds up from there to end up as star, as normally globally as any movie plot has. The difference is, the way its being told, presented, edited. The art of story telling gives your altogether different experience. Every Character in movie has a unique dream and has their own chase and struggle, which makes it as a extraordinary. I am sure director and editor has chopped of tons of scenes before the current releaseversion.@RanveerOfficial performance as #GullyBoy is very contained unlike his other films where his energy overflows the character. He is very cool & mature. One sentence review for his performance is "iske jaisa koi hard ich nahin hai"People who criticizes @RanveerOfficial for overacting, must watch this movie and notice how much he has been calmed down Which woman should take credit #ZoyaAkhtar or #DeepikaPadukone? :)If you feel woman empowerment doesnot get place in bollywood, then believe it that writer & directors blue eyed character in movie is @Alia08. Both #ReemaKagti & #ZoyaAkhtar has made #Saifeena witty, bold, fiesty, intelligent and cute all in one. @Alia08 plays it as naturally as if she is portraying herself. The dream character portraitisation.Debutant @SiddhantChturvD as MJSher gets grand entry where he rips apart with his rap and he is also fabulous as influencer and mentor to #GullyBoy. Somewhere down the storyline, his character may have been shortened, though role weightage is equal to hero and he impresses very well.Each character has depth and Each character makes their character lively be it #Moen by #VijayVerma, #Sky by #Kalki, #VijayRaaz, #borivali guy #KaamBhari and any other characters be it.@ZoyaAkhtarOff has just sealed a power packed movie and presented to the audience to experience the #FunVisphot. She doesn't let any character to slow down and keep them bustling, turning movie a fast paced. when GullyBoy Title caption shows up to the screen, people realises.. ohhh.. the movie has ended.. The audience left with needing more to crave for.#GullyBoy music is first of its kind with full fledged #HipHop album. All Songs are youthful and lovable.#GullyBoy is add up to maturing of Bollywood. Just like content driven and focused approach, this movie focuses on entertainment and stick to core. one more noteworthy point is, The movie has score of songs, but you will realise that not a single one for movie heroine. This is the way each character is deep dived and unnecessary things are cut-off. One more instance is, In one of the post break up scenes, just to make sky understand value of saifeena, gully boy tells, without her, his life will become very lonely between childhood and youth. This is how relationship is valued, you give weightage to past, just not leave them for opportunity of future.#GullyBoy is Youthful movie of this Decade.(Check yourself out which one was yours when you were in 20s)

PEOPLEEEEE!!!!!!! It's very rare that a film ignites something in me so big that makes me want to take everyone I know to go see this movie. Let's start from the top!
Storyline:
This is a story about the underground hip hop scene with a "dreams are bigger than your reality" angle to the storyline.Characters:
The characters are the soul and life of the film. They are exceptionally written and fleshed out. Ranveer Singh as Murad is breathtaking and dare I say, in one of his career best performances. Murad is quiet and surpressed by his circumstances and his reality. But his eyes, oh his eyes, reveal the fire inside him raging to explode. Ranveer Singh taps into a quieter part of himself to bring this character to life and take him straight into your heart. Alia Bhatt as Safeena is quirky, fearless, unpredictable and borderline crazy. It's so refreshing to see a love interest in a Hindi movie that is not perfect and pretty all the time and is so real and three dimensional. Hats off to Zoya Akthar and team for creating this firehouse of a character. Sidhant Chaturvedi as MC Sher, the rapper that takes Murad under his wing is awesome and loveable in the most unexpected of ways. MC Sher takes all the compassion, swagger and passion and nestles himself in your heart. Loved this character! Vijay Raaz as Murad's father is amazing. A man shaped by his circumstances and life and a survivalist in the truest of sense. It was amazing seeing the range of emotion as a conservative Indian Father from him, truly well done . The side characters like Murad's Mother, Grandmother, Brother, his versatile group of friends , his aunt, uncle were all splendid and a treat to watch in the film. They all added to the storyline in their own ways. Zoya Akthar's innate ability to make her characters three dimensional and on top of that have them all add something to the storyline AND have the audience rooting for each one is admirable and genius.Set Design:
This film is almost entirely shot in Dharavi, Mumbai. All the swerving gullies, cramped homes with each inch being utilized is believable and real and really sets the tone for the whole movie. This film is like a love letter to Dharavi and dang I'm here for it.Dialogue:
The dialogue in the film is entirely written in the Mumbai/Hip Hop lingo and I am obsessed with it. However, the best part is the lingo is written in a way that still adds the appropriate flavour to the movie without alienating audiences that have never heard this kind of lingo before. It's very tough balance to maintain in a "dialect/lingo" film but it is achieved beautifully and is really the best way to transport audiences into Murad's world. #apnatimeaayega #dhoptungi #bohothardMusic:
It would be the biggest unjustice to review this film and not talk about the music. The music in this film is EPIC! Every single track in this film was simply awesome and adds to the storyline so well. The rap in this film is the key to Murad's inner mind and it's an amazing place to be. Even if you aren't a huge rap person, I garuntee you will love and appreciate all the lyrics and music of this film.Cinematography:
The cinematography of this film is MINDBLOWING!!!!! The camera angles say so much when the gully's that Murad are running through are shot in a close tight frame making you feel claustraohopic and when the terraces where Murad practices rap with MC Sher are shot with open and wide angles. You realize the camera is talking to you and showing you what Murad is feeling in his environment. OUTSTANDING!!!!!Direction:
Zoya Akthar KILLS IT with this movie!!! Zoya Akthar is a freaking queen and genius mastermind. Zoya Akthar you're a gift to cinema. That's all you need to know, this story was in very able hands and Zoya Akthar delivers beyond expectation.Final Thoughts:
This one of the best films I have seen in a very long time and it had easily made its way into my top five favourite films list, which is saying a lot. A beautiful film that everyone needs to see. There's lots to see, appreciate and resonate with. You can see it with your entire family and I am sure everyone will love it.

Gully Boy - Movie Review.By- Ray Hill.When they first launched the trailer of this movie, people started criticizing that saying it's a rip off of Eminem's 8 mile. And, after watching the movie, after reading a whole lot of great reviews of this movie, I must say that those people don't make sense. Cause, Gully Boy wasn't like 8 mile or anywhere near 8 mile. Cause you see, 8 mile was a great f'ing movie. And, talking about Gully Boy on the other hand was somewhere between Zoya Akhtar's fantasy and Bollywood melodrama.So, Zoya Akhtar did it again. I mean, her life must have been so f'ing easy to make this type of film again again and again. In the starting credit it says the movie is inspired from these two Indian rapper divine and naezy, I'm still not sure how much she got inspiration from them making this movie. For her, no matter how poor the protagonist is, he or she still got a richer lifestyle than any of us, middle class or lower middle class people. It's not all bad, it's kinda cool to watch, but when you are watching it knowing Zoya Akhtar made this, then it's kinda irritating.Now, let's talk about the movie. The movie itself is better than mainstream Bollywood movies, that's for sure. But, what I can say is they tried. And, it's not Zoya Akhtar's best work for sure. Probably, one of her most clumsy work. The thing is it's a long movie, two and a half hours. And the funny thing is, if you just remove the first half it's still the same movie or maybe a better version of it. Yeah, the first half was super boring and clueless. And, the second half is full of emotional dialogues about success, choosing the right road and lecturing the protagonist's Indian dad about chasing his dream and stuffs. We have seen those million times. But, one thing I can say is this movie is full of hypocrisy.So, I'm not sure why, but like all other movies of Zoya Akhtar, Kalki Koechlin appeared in this movie too. And, she was absolutely, from this ultra rich family and she was studying music in the US and was spray painting stuffs all over Mumbai at night with Gully Boy, the protagonist. Now, I have no idea what that scene was doing there, but the spray paints were used to write stuff like "nature was here" in an industrial building front gate and "brown and beautiful" over a fairness cream advertisement. So, what I think, she was trying to give us a "message" about capitalism and stuffs and it was f'ing weird coming from Zoya Akhtar. And, It was even weirder when you got an Adidas sponsorship and your protagonist is riding a luxury SUV to spray paint over capitalist society. I mean, my hands automatically started clapping just watching that whole mess, and to be honest with like thousands of other scenes that scene totally had no connection with the movie. As, I said before if you remove half of the movie, it'll still be the same movie.Now, I read a lot of good reviews before decided to watch this film and I gotta say it's not a complete disaster but it was some kinda typhoon or so. And to end that, I must say 8 mile was like adidas and Gully Boy was simply abidas.

reviews.review_title: Apna time agaya? This one is a perfect
reviews.content:
Bollywood and music pair is like Romeo & Juliet. Truly made for each other. Together they have successfully traveled from Classical to Pop. So how different is this one? Is Gully Boy just a musical bonanza for rap lovers?
The script is simple yet delivers a powerful message on self-belief, hard work, following one's passion & ensuing success. The pace of the movie is brisk and dialogues peppy, which covers up for 2 hrs 36 mins of the long reel. Zoya Akhtar (director) & Reema Kagti (writer & screenplay) have done good work. And the actors have done a splendid job too. Difficult to judge who was better amongst Vijay Raaz, Siddhant Chaturvedi, Vijay Sharma, Alia & Ranveer. Of course, the last name being cherry on the cake. Brilliant work dude! If acting is the heart of Gully Boy then music is its soul. I am no lover of Rap neither do I have much knowledge of it but whatever I heard on screen today was terrific. Lovely lyrics, melting music & bombastic beats. Definitely a deadly deal! Often we get confused with musical dramas, whether it's more of M or D. Thankfully, this one strikes a perfect balance which makes it a hit, at least for the younger generation and those who are young at heart.
Masterpiece, it is beyond any comments. Must watch.

Zoya Akhtar has shown the world how to make a movie and not just some broken stories tied by a single thread so as to be described as a movie. It is the most intense work from her till date. And she has done it with elan. I see no reason why this movie will not be called a CLASSIC in the coming years.
It was not only about direction. The story stands out too. It has the right amount of intensity and quirkiness to keep you seated throughout. The cinematography is brilliant and the way Dharavi has been portrayed is stupendous. You will be hard pressed to find a fault in this whole presentation.
A movie is half good if the casting is not upto the mark. This movie again hits the bull's eye. Each and every role has been portrayed aptly except the role of Kalki, maybe. Kalki was the only not so strong part of the movie. Ranvir and Alia have proved that the future of Bollywood is in safe hands and we will keep getting movies of this calibre in the coming years. Siddhant is the one who takes the limelight. Such a good debut. You won't be able to tell that seeing him in the movie. Vijay Raj is as good as he has been throughout his career. We want to see more of him and he proves it in every way he could.
Music, for me, was not the strongest thing of the movie. Some songs are good but others are not. But they don't spoil the tempo of the movie in any manner.
Overall, this movie is like ZNMD. You can watch it over and over again, if you are able to connect to it. The mannerisms are different, but you will get used to it after the first 15 minutes. The movie runs for almost 2 hours 40 mins and it is a smooth sail. It slows down a bit in the second half but is still butter smooth. A must watch definitely. Thank you Zoya Akhtar for making it. Siddhant has impressed me heavily and I will wait to see more of such works from him.

I've just returned from the cinema after watching Gully Boy. Gully Boy is a story about dreams and a man's struggle to realize his dreams. This is not a subject matter that hasn't been dealt with before. But this is a film done right. Inspired from the real life struggles of rappers Nazey and Divine, Gully Boy tells the story of Murad, who later becomes titular Gully Boy. When the film starts Murad is just a college student who likes Rap and Hip Hop music and also likes to write lyrics of his own. He sees MC Sher, played by Sidhant Chaturvedi, performing in his college and it is this moment that begins his journey to the rap, his own rags to riches story. Murad leads many lives. He is a son, of a poor family, who has to put both, his studies and his music career, on the sides as he has to take up jobs to support his family. He is a son to a father who has a very narrow point of view of the world and to a mother who gets treated horribly by her husband. He has to retort to stealing vehicles with his friend Moin in when he is in dire need of money to support his mother.The script is very well written and the direction is equally good. No moment and no lines in the film are wasted. Every moment and every line of spoken dialogue helps carry the film forward. And it is because of this reason that the film never feels like a drag because it has a runtime of 155 minutes and most films with such a long runtime feel slow at parts, but not Gully Boy. The nicely written script has been complimented by the very good cinematography of the film. In a very subtle way it captures the essence of the gully and the rap scene. When the MCs are spitting bars you feel like you're standing in the crowd and when Murad is running through the streets of Mumbai, specifically the gully, you feel like you're just another man standing in the gully. The camera captures the many unstable, dry and sometimes colourful lives of the films many characters.Music is the core, the heart of this film and all the songs are very well placed and very cleverly used. The songs hit you hard and will make you clap and nod along, doesn't matter if you're a fan of Hip Hop music or not. Real rappers with real talent are at work here and they have given us songs that are both very deep and entertaining at the same time. Besides Nazey and Divine we have songs and performances from real underground rappers like Emiway and these people are in their A game in the film.Gully Boy might have Ranveer Singh as it's lead, who is terrific in the film. It might be his career best performance so far. But it's not just about him. Alia Bhatt at this point has become one of those actors who will give their best and leave a lasting impression on the audience every time they are on the screen. She and Ranveer Singh have a natural chemistry which is reflected on the big screen.
It's not only these two, every single actor in the film has given an amazing performance. And it's because of their engaging performances one leaves the theatre witnessing not only the story of Murad, but also the story of his father, mother, MC Sher, Moin, his girlfriend and many other gully people.Gully Boy showcases the classic struggle between dreams and reality. It is a good film, not only because of the reasons mentioned above but also because it leaves you with many characters to root for. Mourad's father is not supportive of his son's decision to become a rapper and you cannot hate him for it because of the actors convincing performance and because of the reasons that he gives. Gully Boy does not glorify any aspect of life, it rather presents things in a very matter of fact way. It's on us to decide what to do and what not to do. These are the characters from Mumbai that have been presented to us before too. In fact, it is very much a Mumbai film as well. You cannot take away Mumbai from this film and put any other city and hope to make it work.Gully Boy is sure to inspire many young people and make a lot of people think. Even if you're someone who does not like Rap and Hip Hop Gully Boy will not disappoint you at all because it is film well made and it tells the story that all of us can relate to. Watch it for the many lives it covers and look for many stories that unfold.

reviews.review_title: Heart touching, poetic, inspiring, well shot and acted!!

4. Music
5. Cinematography
6. Supporting Cast
So I entered into it with lot of expectations and most of them were met. The narration was fluid and enhanced by natural acting of overall cast. Kudos to Director, Production and Cinematographer for choosing the real locations, it brought lot of authenticity. The best part was overall music (background + OST) and it effective placement.
Some characters and narrative pieces lacked the depth. The supporting characters should have given some more sequence to build their narration more effectively.
The chemistry between the characters was handled creatively.
Ranveer shined throughout in almost every sequence, especially the emotional pieces. Alia proves that she could pull off any character. Siddhant as MC Sher has done a tremendous job, looking forward to his next roles.
Zoya and Reema proved again, how creative storyteller they are. Every one of their projects has excited me.

reviews.review_title: GULLY BOY - Not your typical rags to riches story.
reviews.content:
Gully boy isn't your typical rags to riches story. In fact, it tries to stay as far away from it as possible. The protagonist doesn't become too successful, the lives of many characters have little to no improvement. This movie deals with the fact that everything doesn't go right for everyone.
Set in Mumbai's Dharavi locality, the movie takes us through the journey of a young man, born into poverty, unsure of himself and his future. His love for writing songs and rapping is not supported by his family. This movie shows us how Muraad(Ranveer Singh) overcomes a lot of obstacles to pursue his dream of becoming a rapper.
The movie showcases an acting powerhouse. From Ranveer Singh's silent performance that speaks volumes and Alia bhatt's explosive acting, to Siddhant Chaturvedi(MC Sher), Vijay Raaz(Muraad's dad), Vijay Verma(Muraad's friend) and many more, this movie is sure to impress you with it's acting performances. The scenes with Muraad and his father are emotionally compelling and some of the best in the movie.
This movie touches apon many topics such as polygamy, child labour, feminism, etc. but still manages to stay true to the main story.
The first half is quite slow, but the second half is a lot more gripping. All in all, it is a movie that is enjoyable, but may not be your first choice if you're deciding on which movie to watch on a Friday night.
6/10

Folks, there is a concert going on in cinema halls next to you and the name is Gully Boy !Based on the real story of our own backyard rappers from the gully of Dharavi, Naezy and Divine, Zoya Akhtar spins a story of inspiration, aspiration, passion and grim reality.It will remind at least some of my gen guys of Tupac Shakur, Eminem, Notorious etc.. and of course the cult classic 8 Mile. If 8 Mile was the story of a white boy breaking into the domain of rap genre, Gully Boy is the story of struggle against poverty and aspiring something totally out of league with the environment, the protagonist lives in.Ranveer rocks the part of the rapper. This actor with every new role is redefining indian cinema. At the start of the movie, you may not even recognize him, loafing around with his pals, without his quirky dressing sense and loud get-ups. His intensity doubles up even when he does not have dialogues to mouth, and the expressions are enough to convey the thoughts. He is at the top of his game.But the one that takes your heart, is Alia Bhatt. Hear her as Safeena speaking to Murad at the bus stop. She is a natural, and so is Siddhant Chaturvedi aka MC Sher. The way he speaks, the dialogues that he has, his body language and the confidence that he has in himself despite being from the same slums makes him an anchor to all around him including Murad - Ranveer aka Gully Boy.The music which to some ages, may not be palatable, does to Rap genre in Indian context, what probably 8 Mile did. Just hear the first one "Jingo-staan Zindabad", it is sure to give you goosebumps. Of course Apna time aayega is on its way to be top of the charts.Zoya Akhtar excels in every department, and this is not a movie but a poem that sprang out of the true story of Neazy and Divine. Dont miss it.

Let me confess one thing first. I am not a fan of rap song and dint know much about rappers.Now coming to the review. Gully Boy" is a film about a 22-year-old boy "Murad" from a ghetto in Mumbai, India. The son of a driver, his parents worked hard to get him educated so that he could have a white collar job. Meanwhile, Murad realizes his calling to be a rapper. Authentic Hip Hop in India is a recent phenomenon and like anywhere else in the world, is rising from the streets. Art is a distant dream for the colonized poor of India and this story is about Murad's journey from realizing his love for rap and chasing his dream to inadvertently transcending his class. The film showcases street rap from the crevices of Mumbai's by lanes. The poetry is conscious of the city's socio-economic fabric and highlights the challenges faced by the disenfranchised youth in the minority population.

It's one of the many rousing moments in Zoya Akhtar's superb new film. Gully Boy is loosely based on the lives of real life rappers Naezy and DIVINE, who rose from slums to stardom. Hip hop, modern day protest music, which came out of the streets of New York, has inspired a flourishing music scene in Mumbai. But the beauty of Gully Boy is that even if you are entirely unfamiliar with this world, like I was, the film will still stir your soul. It chronicles the story of an ordinary boy Murad, from Dharavi, who dreams big and refuses to let adversity squash his spirit. His journey from being the quintessential slumdog to being an ambitious rapper named Gully Boy, is exhilarating and exciting, to say the least. Rap is an unconventional genre of music in India, but even those who don't necessarily associate with this form of music, will be able appreciate the underdog and heartfelt story.
The writing, the emotions, the brilliance, every song is simply MIND-BLOWING! there will be no one who has faced tough situations in their life are are struggling to pursue and reach their goals. Every spectacular dialogue, the brilliantly conveyed social message, the cast, the crew and finally the film, just outstanding and simply perfect how the whole movie surround a single plot of struggling towards a committed goal. One thing which I noticed was that most of the songs have been sung by Ranveer himself & he scores high there. This movie is not just another movie, it talks about the struggle, identity and dream. The relation with God was also part of the struggle.This movie will strike a mark on your heart. You will not forget the felling of working for your dreams and make your own identity.Less compelling is a subplot involving Kalki Koechlin's character as Sky, an affluent, US-returned musician who takes a keen interest both in Murad's music and him. Aside from a few such plot points that I wasn't entirely convinced about, my only really issue with the film is its length. Perhaps because there's so much going on onscreen, and because the filmmakers take the trouble to tie up each character's story, the film is way too long. It's nearly two and a half hours and that's too long for a film whose basic story arc - the underdog narrative - is actually quite predictable.
But those minor niggling's aside, Without overtly drawing attention to it, she makes a strong feminist statement in Alia Bhutt's character, some sharp observations about minorities, and also about the world we live in and the place in it for those with lesser means.If want to see some real life hiccups, some real life struggle by passing all hiccups you should definitely watch this and most importantly you would love this movie if you like raps.

The story of the underdog making good is a reasonably familiar trope for Bollywood. Amitabh Bachchan had made the genre his own when he ruled as the 'angry young man.' Usually such stories also include an element of moral redemption and exploit the familiar theme of cops and robbers all the way from the sibling rivalry where Sashi Kapoor famously says 'mere pass Ma hain' to the more contemporary saga of the 'Sacred Games'. The story of Gully Boy while including many elements of the familiar also provides an alternative exploration of subaltern masculinities.
Dharavi provides a very realistic and human backdrop but unlike in Slumdog Millionaire it reverberates with a joie de vivre. Instead of evoking the pathos of the well-heeled viewer it indicts the wide-eyed incredulous 'gaze' of poverty tourism when the grandmother makes a quick 500 rupees by letting the guide bring in the white camera toting foreign tourists into her home. Guiltily I recalled my own experience entering the hovels of a Masai camp near Ngorongoro, clicking away in wonder.
Ranveer Singh (Murad) in the title role is a Dharavi youth who knows that he has to secure a college degree to get ahead in life. His close friend Moeen is in the more familiar 'tapori' mould. He sells drugs and steals cars, sometimes just for a lark and a joy ride. The third character is MC Sher, a 'rapper' who both inspires and mentors Murad in 'rapping'. Unlike the other two he is not Muslim and instead of Dharavi lives in a one room chawl where he keeps his many sneakers secure in a safe. These three young men are all from the more marginal sections of Mumbai society but they are different and their differences don't seem at all contrived
There is a very interesting 'bro-code' in their relationships throughout the two and half hours of the film. Sher is already an icon among college students when Murad asks him to use his lyrics in his rap. Sher refuses to use the more 'powerful' poetry of Murad and instead encourages him to 'rap' and takes him under his tutelage. This support is unwavering even when mentor is knocked out of the 'rap' competition and the mentorship continues till the end. With Moeen the relationship is a little more complex. Murad is shown as a reluctant participant in the joy ride in a stolen car in the opening sequence of the film. He also rebukes Moeen for using children to peddle ganja (cannabis). Moeen will have none of this moral lecture and one senses that their relationship is perhaps doomed to end on moral grounds, but it does not. When Murad walks out of his father's home along with brother and mother, Moeen's garage is his first port of call. Moeen is the only one he knows who can make money by bending the rules. Murad becomes a willing associate to a string of car liftings and using this money sets up his new home. When Moeen is picked up by the police Murad is willing to share the rap with him but Moeen refuses. He says that Murad has a better chance to make 'good' and should stay out.
Gully Boy is a film about young men and rap music. Rap competitions in the form of a face off between rappers is a running theme in the film. The key to winning is to run down your opponent. Murad is hesitant in the beginning and is not at all comfortable in belittling his opponent. He avoids this attacking style which is more popular with other rappers. Instead he uses a more reflective style where social observations around poverty and inequality form the core of his poetry. He too is an angry young man but the film completely avoids physical violence as a means of getting back at society.
While the film is primarily about men there are a couple of strong female characters as well. Alia Bhatt plays the role of Safeena, Murad's love interest. She is from a conservative middle-class Muslim family and is training to be a doctor. Dressed demurely in a hijab she is explosively independent and thinks nothing of hitting another woman with a beer bottle, when she thinks she is 'poaching' her man. Kalki Koechlin is 'Sky', the other young woman who is very unconventional. She is from the high society of Mumbai, and studies in the US. She is keen to produce a track with the rappers. She also a rebel and provides a counterpoint to the existing socio-economic order when she sprays graffiti and defaces posters of anorexic models and fairness creams. Murad's relationships with these two young women are important but somehow seem less significant than that with Moeen and MC Sher.
The film offers a fresh perspective to subaltern masculinities which are currently much maligned. The Nirbhaya case from Delhi and the Shakti Mills case of Mumbai have highlighted the intense sexual violence associated with young men from the margins. The current political climate of intolerance is being fuelled through the same demographic who are being encouraged see their enemy in the 'other'. Across the world rapid social and economic changes along with dispossession and economic inequality have created some of the most virulent expressions of male violence and hatred. Male youth see their many masculine entitlements challenged and threatened. The political and economic powers have been able to focus the attention away from more fundamental questions of equity and justice and towards convenient 'enemies' like ethnic and religious minorities and women. Within this context Zoya Akhtar has done a remarkable job in presenting the story of young men from the underbelly of Mumbai in a very human manner without using any hyperbole, violence or sex. The men are clearly dispossessed but they are observant and analytic as well. They bend the rules for fun and for survival but they are not evil or malicious. Within an ambience of competition the film provides a strong message of empathy and solidarity. Gully Boy is a contemporary film celebrating eternal human values, a film worth watching even if you are not into rap.

8-Mile-ish, Gully Boy is the first and only Bollywood movie I've seen that revolves around the desi rap culture. It does a great job in portraying Mumbai's amateur rap scene, and that it does with very impressive rap lyrics whose flow doesn't seem synthetic. One on one rap battles seemed a bit ersatz, but 'Salim Shady', as someone calls Murad in an earlier scene, does deliver a whistle-grabber.Halfway through, I realized the movie incorporated all the elements of a natural, 'everyday' story of a group of happening biographical figures! Vijay Raaz's exceptionally fluent acting; Kalki doing her best at portraying her character of a free soul drawn to music; mellifluous yet manly rap tunes; attention grabbing sub-plots like that of Kalki's gang artistically protesting fair-skin and body-shape taboo by blacking-out posters; the quintessential, forever ongoing bickering of Dharavi - the movie had it all. It even included in a way, the no-Youtube 90s era movie trick of building up the hype by offering hums and tunes all through the movie of its central song that would finally roar at a later point in the movie. Apna Time Aayega, in this particular case.The meat of the movie, though, was a firecracker performance by Alia which can easily earn her many award nominations, a mind-blowingly cool performance by the debutant Siddharth Chaturvedi in his role of the humble but Hard (pun intended) MC Sher, and the remarkable narrative by Zoya and Reema that's down-to-earth and pragmatic, uncustomary to mainstream Bollywood story-telling. Add to this a very modest, uncomplex, sincere, and hunky-dory performance by Ranveer who very much forms the crux of the whole story.Overall, I found the movie to almost fall into the category of "Must Watch"es, though I'd say one would find it terrifically captivating only if the person is contextually aware of the history, evolution, and reception of rap culture in general.

reviews.review_title: The Glorious Journey of Gully Boy
reviews.content: Ever since I have watched this movie, I can't get it out of my head. It is everything you want if you adore the craft of filmmaking; intricate, intense, charming and revolutionary. In the simplest of words, it is a masterpiece. The journey of Murad is his, and the viewer's at the same time. The story unfolds beautifully and just gets better. Ranveer and Alia shine, Zoya's direction strikes and the music is perfect. Don't expect to find commercialised senseless 'rap' from the item songs, this is from the heart, as in, ACTUAL rap.Firstly, I salute the team. Every aspect of this film is absolutely stunning. Ranveer Singh proves that he isn't here on the basis of luck, the movie belongs to him. His performance is fascinating and the fact that he did all the raps himself makes it even more special. Alia Bhatt delivers what you expect from her - perfection, she really is the finest actress of this generation. Zoya Akhtar is a master director. No one could have presented such a different film in such a remarkable way. Cinematography, editing - its all gorgeous.The soundtrack has a soul of its own and acts as the one of the biggest strengths of this film. The lyrics, expression, beats and Ranveer Singh's voice mesmerizes everyone who listens to it. Divine did a great job at composing the music. The whole background score and songs are all beautiful.Gully Boy is an inspiring piece of art and is the ultimate ode to the dreamers - to everyone. Take that chance! Bohot hard hai bhai!
